backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f2c\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f2c\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f2c\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f2c\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f2d_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0BELLS strong gravitational lens galaxies and foreground-subtracted images. The 36 grade-A, -B, and -C lenses discovered under <em>HST</em> cycle 18 program 12209. For each system, the left panel shows the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC F814W rectified and combined images with north up and east to the left, and the right panel reveals the lensed features which remain after the foreground galaxy has been subtracted by the B-spline method described in Section\u00a0<a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s3\">3</a>. Probable non-lensed extraneous features that were masked are circled. System properties from the BOSS data are listed in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t2\">2</a>, and those from the <em>HST</em>-ACS data are listed in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t3\">3</a>. Comments justifying our lens grade are provided in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t4\">4</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f2d\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f2d\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f2d\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f2d\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s4\" name=\"apj413791s4\">4.\u00a0PHOTOMETRIC ANALYSIS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>To compute standardized model magnitudes, effective radii, projected axis ratios, and position angles for the BELLS targets, we fit the images to two-dimensional ellipsoidal de Vaucouleurs luminosity profiles. These fits are performed over a 51'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 51'' square region centered on the target galaxies (approximately half the narrower dimension of the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC CCD aperture in which the targets were roughly centered). The 14'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 14'' masks created with our <tt>ACSPROC</tt> software described in Step\u00a05 of Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s3\">3</a> are applied in the central regions; stars and neighboring galaxies outside the manually masked area are masked with a single-step \"clipping\" of pixels that deviate by more than four standard deviations from the model. The fits are performed using the <tt>MPFIT2DFUN</tt> procedure in the <tt>IDL</tt> programming language, using a flat-weighted inverse variance, and include convolution with the appropriate rectified and stacked <tt>Tiny Tim</tt> PSF (Krist <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r26\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r26\">1993</a>). The initial optimization is done by sampling the model at one point per data pixel and repeated with a 5 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 5 sub-sampling per pixel.</p><p>The <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band apparent magnitudes are computed from the full (not truncated) analytic integral of the best-fit de Vaucouleurs model and provided in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t3\">3</a>. We also report the corrections for Galactic extinction from Schlegel et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r34\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r34\">1998</a>). Photometric stellar masses are computed from the extinction corrected <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band apparent magnitudes using the Maraston et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r28\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r28\">2009</a>) LRG photometric stellar population model with a Salpeter initial mass function. We use the intermediate axis effective radius (the geometric mean of the major and minor axes).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj413791t3\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 3.</b>\u00a0<em>HST</em>-ACS <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band Properties of BELLS Systems</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791t3\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t3_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 3\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">System Name</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><span rowspan=\"1\">17.859</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.079</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.434 \u00b1 0.001</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.929 \u00b1 0.001</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">122.9 \u00b1 0.1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">L-S-A</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J2122+0409</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">19.501</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.147</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.903 \u00b1 0.002</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.819 \u00b1 0.002</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">136.6 \u00b1 0.3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">E-S-A</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J2125+0411</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">18.271</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.150</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.901 \u00b1 0.001</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.689 \u00b1 0.001</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">111.0 \u00b1 0.1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">E-S-A</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J2303+0037</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">18.721</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.081</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.349 \u00b1 0.002</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.760 \u00b1 0.001</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">\u200384.4 \u00b1 0.1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">E-S-A</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> Column 1 provides the SDSS system name in terms of truncated J2000 R.A. and decl. in the format HHMM\u00b1DDMM. Column 2 provides <em>HST</em>-ACS <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band apparent magnitudes based on flat-weighted de Vaucouleurs models and are quoted in the <em>AB</em> system (Oke &amp; Gunn <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r31\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r31\">1983</a>) without correction for Galactic extinction. Column 3 provides Schlegel et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r34\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r34\">1998</a>) Galactic extinction values that should be subtracted from the apparent magnitudes of Column\u00a02 to give dust-corrected magnitudes. Column 4 provides de Vaucouleurs model intermediate axis effective radii. Column 5 provides axis ratios of minor to major axes, <em>B</em>/<em>A</em>, for the de Vaucouleurs models. Column 6 provides the major axis position angles for the de Vaucouleurs models, measured east from north. Column 7 provides our classification denoting (1) foreground-galaxy morphology, (2) foreground-galaxy multiplicity, and (3) status of system as a lens based on available data. Morphology is coded by \"E\" for early-type (elliptical and S0), \"L\" for late-type (Sa and later), and \"U\" for unclassified (galaxies that cannot be unambiguously classed as early- or late-type based on the <em>HST</em>-ACS <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band data). Multiplicity is coded by \"S\" for single and \"M\" for multiple. Lens grades, as justified in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t4\">4</a>, are coded by \"A\" for systems with clear and convincing evidence of multiple imaging, \"B\" for systems with strong evidence of multiple imaging but insufficient S/N for definite conclusion and/or modeling, \"C\" for systems with evidence of imaging such as single arcs or likely background features, but without detected counterimages, and \"X\" for all other systems (non-lenses).\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t3_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t3_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Figure\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f3\">3</a> shows that the distribution of grade-A lenses in <em>HST</em> <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band magnitudes is similar to that of the SLACS sample, lying at higher redshifts, but within the same stellar mass range of 10<sup>11</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <em>M</em><sub><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sstarf.gif\" alt=\"sstarf\" align=\"baseline\" /></sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>. The distribution in the ratio \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>/<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> of the Einstein radius to the lens effective radius as a function of the lens redshift is shown in Figure\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f4\">4</a>. The BELLS sample extends the SLACS sample to a wider range of \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>/<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> while still providing substantial overlap with the range of ratios seen in the SLACS sample.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj413791f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Distribution of confirmed SLACS and BELLS lens <em>HST</em> <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band magnitudes, shown as a function of lens redshift. SLACS lenses are shown with red squares, and BELLS lenses are shown with blue diamonds. Stellar masses are indicated by the 10<sup>11</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> upper track and 10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> lower track with black dashed lines, based upon the stellar population model of Maraston et\u00a0al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r28\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r28\">2009</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj413791f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Distribution of the ratio between the Einstein radii and the effective radii, as a function of lens redshift. SLACS lenses are shown with red squares, and BELLS lenses are shown with blue diamonds.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Each of the <em>HST</em>-ACS <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band images was visually inspected to classify all targets for multiplicity and morphology. Systems with two or more foreground galaxies of comparable luminosity are classified as \"multiple,\" while systems with only a single-dominant foreground galaxy are classified as \"single.\" Morphological classification is limited to the categories of \"early-type\" (elliptical and S0), \"late-type\" (Sa and later spirals), and \"unclassified\" (generally ambiguous between S0 and Sa). The classification of observed candidates into lenses and non-lenses is made by visual examination of the direct and B-spline model-subtracted residuals, based on the appearance of arcs, rings, and multiple images centered on the position of the foreground galaxy. Our classification is provided in the Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t3\">3</a>, with our justifications for BELLS confirmed lenses provided in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t4\">4</a>.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj413791t4\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 4.</b>\u00a0BELLS Confirmed Gravitational Lenses</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791t4\" background-galaxy arc to the southwest, but no evidence of a counterimage.</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> Column 1 provides the SDSS system name in terms of truncated J2000 R.A. and decl. in the format HHMM\u00b1DDMM. Column 2 provides our lens grade, coded by \"A\" for the 25 systems with clear and convincing evidence of multiple imaging, \"B\" for the three systems with strong evidence of multiple imaging but insufficient S/N for definite conclusion and/or modeling, and \"C\" for the eight systems with evidence of imaging such as single arcs or likely background features, but without detected counterimages. Column 3 provides our lens-grade justification. SIE model parameters for the grade-A lenses are listed in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t5\">5</a>. The remainder of the observed sample, listed in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t6\">6</a>, receives a grade of \"X\" (non-lenses).\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t4_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t4_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s5\" name=\"apj413791s5\">5.\u00a0STRONG-LENSING ANALYSIS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Figure\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f2\">2</a> shows the foreground-subtracted images of each BELLS target that completed the <tt>ACSPROC</tt> image reduction process described in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s3\">3</a>. These are the lensed features which remain after the foreground galaxy has been subtracted. This image is passed forward to the lens modeling stage as the zeroth extension of a <tt>BIZZLE</tt> <tt>FITS</tt> file. In addition, the inverse variance of the foreground-subtracted image, the lensed features mask, the mask for extraneous unlensed features, and the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC PSF are included in successive <tt>FITS</tt> extensions. The best-fit B-spline model parameters of the foreground galaxy are included in the <tt>FITS</tt> header so that the center of the lens model may be constrained by the luminous distribution, and so that the ellipticity of the visible galaxy may be used to initialize the lens model. These BELLS <tt>BIZZLE</tt> files are input into our <tt>ACSLENS</tt> software, implemented in the <tt>Python</tt> programming language, which accommodates the SIE lens model (Kassiola &amp; Kovner <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r20\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r20\">1993</a>; Kormann et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r25\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r25\">1994</a>; Keeton &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r21\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r21\">1998</a>) and both parametric or pixelized source models.</p><p>The SIE model is a two-dimensional potential of similar concentric and aligned elliptical isodensity contours, with axis ratio <em>q</em><sub>SIE</sub>. The projected surface density of the SIE falls off as 1/<em>R</em> and the model provides flat galaxy rotation curves. The model is parameterized by its angular Einstein radius, \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>, which is related to the physical mass model through\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj413791fd1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791fd1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} \\theta _{E} = 4 \\pi {{\\sigma _{\\mathrm{SIE}}^2} \\over {c^2}} {D_{LS} \\over D_S}, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where \u03c3<sub>SIE</sub> is a velocity-dispersion parameter and <em>D</em><sub>LS</sub> and <em>D<sub>S</sub></em> are cosmological angular diameter distances from lens and observer to source, respectively. We adopt the intermediate axis normalization of Kormann et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r25\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r25\">1994</a>), whereby the mass within a given isodensity contour remains constant at fixed \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub> for changing <em>q</em><sub>SIE</sub>.</p><p>We attempt to model all candidate lenses with an SIE lens-mass model and a parametric source-plane surface-brightness model, where the source may be composed of either single or multiple Gaussian, de Vaucouleurs (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r7\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r7\">1948</a>) or S\u00e9rsic (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r36\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r36\">1968</a>) distributions, as necessary to obtain a good (\u03c7<sup>2</sup>) fit. The model lensed image is generated by ray-tracing through the analytic SIE mass model and then convolved with the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC PSF. After choosing reasonable initial parameter values, the SIE and source-plane model parameters are optimized nonlinearly with the <tt>leastsq</tt> Levenberg\u2013Marquardt implementation in the <tt>scipy.optimize</tt> package. In the SIE mass-model optimization, the mass centroid is fixed to the centroid of the luminous distribution as determined from the B-spline lens-galaxy photometric analysis, while the SIE strength, axis ratio, and major axis position angle are all allowed to vary. The final outcome is a set of lens-model and source-component parameters, along with a model for the lensed images.</p><p>Our best-fit parametric source model is then complemented with a pixelized source plane model, which we compute through a matrix inversion including linear regularization, without re-optimizing the lens model (Warren &amp; Dye <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r43\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r43\">2003</a>; Treu &amp; Koopmans <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r39\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r39\">2004</a>; Wayth &amp; Webster <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r45\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r45\">2006</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r24\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r24\">2006</a>).</p><p>If necessary to obtain a better correspondence between the parametric and pixelized model images, the apparent multiplicity and spatial orientation of the pixelized source distribution are used to place additional S\u00e9rsic sources, and then the parametric model is re-optimized together with the SIE mass-model parameters. Several iterations are pursued until the parametric and pixelized models are in reasonable agreement. Although we do not use the pixelized models in the lens model optimization, their ability to capture more detail in the lensed galaxies serves as an important confirmation of the lensing hypothesis in most cases.</p><p>Our best-fit SIE lens models with S\u00e9rsic source models, along with our pixelized source models, are presented in Figure\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f5\">5</a>, and the best-fit model parameters are listed in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t5\">5</a>. Our justifications for the BELLS confirmed lenses grading are provided in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t4\">4</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj413791f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f5a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; SIE lens models are shown for each of the 25 confirmed-to-date grade-A lenses discovered under <em>HST</em> cycle 18 program ID GO-12209. For each system, the left panel shows the lensed features which remain after foreground-galaxy subtraction by the B-spline method described in Section\u00a0<a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s3\">3</a>, repeated from the rightmost panel of Figure\u00a0<a href=\"#apj413791f2\">2</a>. Best-fit SIE models with S\u00e9rsic sources are shown in the second panel from the left, including the residuals of the data minus the parametric model in the third panel, with the de-lensed S\u00e9rsic source model shown in the fourth panel, at a scale optimized for the source plane. Best-fit SIE model parameters are provided in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t5\">5</a>. SIE models with pixelized sources are shown in the fifth panel from the left, including the residuals of the data minus the pizelized model in the sixth panel, with the de-lensed pixelized source model shown in the rightmost panel, at the same scale as used for the parametric source model. Comments justifying our lens grade are provided in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t4\">4</a>. The color scale is provided in Figure\u00a0<a href=\"#apj413791f2\">2</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f5e\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f5e\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f5e\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f5e\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj413791t5\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 5.</b>\u00a0BELLS Grade-A Strong-lens SIE Model Parameters</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791t5\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t5_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 5\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">System Name</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub> ('')</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><em>q</em><sub>SIE</sub></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">P.A. rowspan=\"1\">3.43</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1234\u22120241</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.533</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.821</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">83.0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">21.11</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4.32</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J2303+0037</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.016</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.391</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">88.8</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">23.10</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">8.06</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> The method used to compute the best-fit SIE model parameters is described in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s5\">5</a>. Column 1 provides the SDSS system name in terms of truncated J2000 R.A. and decl. in the format HHMM\u00b1DDMM. Column 2 provides the best-fit SIE model Einstein radius. Column 3 provides the best-fit minor to major axis ratio for the SIE models. Column 4 provides the major axis position angle for the SIE models, measured east from north. Column 5 provides the number of S\u00e9rsic models added to the source plane to provide the best fit. Column 6 provides the <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band magnitude of the lensed source. Column 7 provides the magnification of the lensed source.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t5_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t5_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s6\" name=\"apj413791s6\">6.\u00a0SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We present 44 of the 45 targets observed-to-date in the BELLS from the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC cycle 18 program ID GO-12209 imaging program. The BELLS catalog presently includes 25 grade-A strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses complete with lens and source redshifts, <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band foreground-galaxy photometry, and SIE models. This represents a significant expansion of the SLACS survey, extending the lens redshifts to <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.66, and with source redshifts extended to <em>z</em><sub>S</sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /> 1.52. The combined SLACS and BELLS catalog provides a homogeneous sample of strong-lens galaxies at significant cosmological look-back times. Future papers in this series will apply the combined SLACS and BELLS samples to the analysis of the structure and evolution of massive elliptical galaxies.</p><p>We have described the use of our <tt>ACSPROC</tt> <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC image processing software to make luminosity measurements and to produce our <tt>BIZZLE</tt> data product. We then analyze the <tt>BIZZLE</tt> data using our <tt>ACSLENS</tt> lens-modeling software to make parameterized and pixelized lens models. Our analysis demonstrates that simple SIE lens models, combined with multiple S\u00e9rsic ellipsoid models of the lensed background galaxies, can reproduce the lensed image configurations in great detail, and our pixelized source models reproduce more detailed features in the lensed images and add finer structure to the de-lensed source model.</p><p>The high success rate of our <em>HST</em> imaging program demonstrates that the spectroscopic strong-lens selection methodology can be successfully applied to the BOSS spectroscopic database even though BOSS is targeting a more distant\u2014and hence fainter\u2014galaxy population than SDSS-I. The probability of finding a galaxy\u2013galaxy lens using the spectroscopic discovery method was considered in Dobler et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r8\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r8\">2008</a>) for the SLACS survey, including selection effects such as the finite size of the spectroscopic fiber (which selects against large separation lenses), and the effectiveness of spectral noise modeling (which selects against sources that have redshifted emission lines coincident with strong emission lines in the sky). The probability that a galaxy\u2013galaxy lens would be spectroscopically discovered from either the SDSS-I or SDSS-III spectra, and lead to a confirmed lens, is under consideration in R. Arneson et\u00a0al. (2011, in preparation) using a Monte Carlo simulation to measure the effects of variation in the lens mass, ellipticity, and morphology, source extent, and the logarithm slope of the lens luminosity profile.</p><p>The strong-lensing measurements presented in this work afford a unique opportunity to test the results of theoretical models and numerical simulations of galaxy formation, merging, and evolution. This is due to the fact that strong-lensing measures the projected mass inside the aperture defined by the Einstein radius, in a nearly model-independent sense, and without need for modeling of stellar populations and luminosity evolution.</p><p>In comparison with the SDSS-I spectra of the SLACS lens sample, the BOSS spectra for the BELLS sample have significantly lower signal to noise. Hence, the resulting velocity-dispersion measurements for the BELLS sample are correspondingly noisier and more care must be taken in interpreting these measurements in the context of dynamical galaxy modeling. Work in preparation will present a joint analysis of all BELLS lenses that marginalizes over the full velocity-dispersion likelihood function for individual spectra (see Shu et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r37\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r37\">2011</a>). Deeper spectroscopy with large ground-based telescopes can provide more precise stellar velocity-dispersion measurements.</p><p>We note that the BOSS spectroscopic database as of summer 2011, which will constitute the ninth SDSS public data release (DR9), contains 819 unique BOSS plates with an average of approximately 600 successfully redshifted galaxies per plate. (The increase in the number of spectroscopically confirmed galaxies per plate was produced by a combination of improvements in targeting, hardware, operations, and analysis software during the BOSS commissioning phase and early operations.) Thus, DR9 is at least a fourfold increase over the sample we used here. The final BOSS sample, to be completed in mid-2014 and released at the end of that year, will be an order of magnitude increase over the sample used here. In addition, ongoing BOSS spectroscopic pipeline development (including implementation of the two-dimensional PSF-based extraction algorithm of Bolton &amp; Schlegel <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r5\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r5\">2010</a>) continues to increase the quality of the reduced spectra and redshift/classification analysis for BOSS significantly. Hence, there will be at least several hundred strong lenses to be found in BOSS spectroscopy at the end of the survey, offering the possibility of measuring the cosmic evolution of the relationship between mass-density structure and stellar mass, luminosity, and rest-frame color, in great quantitative detail.</p></div>\n<div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Support for program 12209 was provided by NASA through a grant from the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. This work has made extensive use of the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey, part of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III (SDSS-III). Funding for SDSS-III has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation, and the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science. The SDSS-III Web site is <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"url_link\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.sdss3.org/\">http://www.sdss3.org/</a>. SDSS-III is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS-III Collaboration including the University of Arizona, the Brazilian Participation Group, Brookhaven National Laboratory, University of Cambridge, University of Florida, the French Participation Group, the German Participation Group, the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, the Michigan State/Notre Dame/JINA Participation Group, Johns Hopkins University, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Max Planck Institute for Astrophysics, New Mexico State University, New York University, Ohio State University, Pennsylvania State University, University of Portsmouth, Princeton University, the Spanish Participation Group, University of Tokyo, University of Utah, Vanderbilt University, University of Virginia, University of Washington, and Yale University. J.R.B. and A.S.B. acknowledge the hospitality of the Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Astronomie, where a portion of this work was completed. C.S.K. is supported by NSF grant AST-1004756.</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791app1\" name=\"apj413791app1\">APPENDIX</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The combined and rectified stacked images for the grade-X systems are included in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f6\">6</a> for completeness. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t6\">6</a> gives the comments justifying the lens grade of \"X\".</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj413791f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0BELLS grade-X non-lens galaxies. The eight non-lenses, discovered to-date under <em>HST</em> cycle 18 program ID GO-12209, Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t2\">2</a> presents their properties as derived from the BOSS data, and Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t3\">3</a> presents those derived from the <em>HST</em> data. For each system, the panel shows the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC F814W rectified and combined images with north up and east to the left. Comments justifying the lens grade of \"X\" are provided in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t6\">6</a>. The color scale is provided in Figure\u00a0<a href=\"#apj413791f2\">2</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj413791t6\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 6.</b>\u00a0BELLS Grade-X Non-lens Galaxies</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791t6\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t6_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 6\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">System Name</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Justification</th>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">(1)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(2)</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody><tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J0757+4313</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Two components with spiral structure; any lensing features are difficult to disentangle.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J0837+4937</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Late-type with faint candidate features, but with no evidence of multiple imaging.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1117\u22120133</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Pronounced asymmetry in the foreground galaxy plus possible spiral and dust features. Column 2 provides our justification for the lens grade of \"X\" (non-lenses).\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t6_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t6_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj413791fn1\" id=\"apj413791fn1\">*\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>Based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>, obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">THE BOSS EMISSION-LINE LENS SURVEY (BELLS). class=\"da1 ta1\">\n                <!-- Start Linked Articles note -->\n\t<!-- End Linked Articles note -->\n<!-- Article information starts. class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n        \t<a id=\"wd-article-info-accordion\" href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide article information\">Article information</a>\n      \t</div>\n      \t<div class=\"reveal-content\">\n        \t<div class=\"article-meta\">\n          \t\t<!-- Start Affiliations --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-author-affiliations\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">Author affiliations</div><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>1</sup> Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>2</sup> New York, NY 10003, USA</p></div><!-- End Affiliations --><!-- Start Dates -->\n<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-dates\">\n        <div class=\"replica-h4\">Dates</div>\n        <p>\n            \n                Received <span itemprop=\"dateReceived\">2011 October 6</span><br />\n            \n                Accepted <span itemprop=\"dateAccepted\">2011 November 16</span><br />\n -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-doi\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<abbr title=\"digital object identifier\">DOI</abbr>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<p><a Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- End Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- Start Annotations -->\n <!-- End Annotations --><div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-aas-keywords\">\n\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">Keywords</div>\n\t\t<p><a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F10&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+distances+and+redshifts\">galaxies: distances and redshifts</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F13&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+evolution\">galaxies: evolution</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F18&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+high-redshift\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F46&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+strong\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F54&amp;code_desc=large-scale+structure+of+universe\">large-scale structure of universe</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=4%2F4&amp;code_desc=surveys\">surveys</a></p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!-- End Reprint Link --><!-- Start Journal RSS                <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n                        Receive alerts on all new research papers in American Astronomical Society\n                        (<span class=\"abbr__aas\">A&nbsp;A&nbsp;S&nbsp;</span>) journals as soon as they are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F744%2F1%2F41\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/744/1/41</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n                      <P>We present a catalog of 25 definite and 11 probable strong galaxy-galaxy gravitational lens systems with lens redshifts 0.4 <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <I>z</I> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.7, discovered spectroscopically by the presence of higher-redshift emission lines within the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) of luminous galaxies, and confirmed with high-resolution <I>Hubble Space Telescope</I> (<I>HST</I>) images of 44 candidates. Our survey extends the methodology of the Sloan Lens Advanced Camera for Surveys survey (SLACS) to higher redshift. We describe the details of the BOSS spectroscopic candidate detections, our <I>HST</I> ACS image processing and analysis methods, and our strong gravitational lens modeling procedure. We report BOSS spectroscopic parameters and ACS photometric parameters for all candidates, and mass-distribution parameters for the best-fit singular isothermal ellipsoid models of definite lenses. Our sample to date was selected using only the first six months of BOSS survey-quality spectroscopic data. The full five-year BOSS database should produce a sample of several hundred strong galaxy-galaxy lenses and in combination with SLACS lenses at lower redshift, strongly constrain the redshift evolution of the structure of elliptical, bulge-dominated galaxies as a function of luminosity, stellar mass, and rest-frame color, thereby providing a powerful test for competing theories of galaxy formation and evolution.</P>       </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/744/1/41&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/744/1/41&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ApJ...744...41B\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2012ApJ...744...41B&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2012ApJ...744...41B\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s1\" name=\"apj413791s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing produces unmistakably distorted, amplified, and multiplied images of a distant galaxy through the gravitational field of a foreground galaxy. This phenomenon provides a direct astrometric measurement of the total mass distribution within the interior of the lens galaxy, including luminous and dark components. Strong lensing on galactic scales was first suggested by Zwicky (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r49\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r49\">1937</a>) and first discovered by Walsh et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r42\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r42\">1979</a>). Since then, a number of dedicated and serendipitous surveys have produced a combined sample of over 200 galaxy-scale lens systems (for a recent review, see Treu <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r38\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r38\">2010</a>). Of the various survey methods, the most prolific means of identifying strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lens candidates is spectroscopic discovery, which provides evidence for two galaxies along one line of sight, along with precise measurements of the lens and source redshifts (Warren et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r44\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r44\">1996</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r4\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r4\">2004</a>). Images taken with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) or other high-resolution facilities then provide a confirmation of the lensing hypothesis and make precise (milliarcsecond) measurements of the relative positions of the components. This method has been employed by the Sloan Lens Advanced Camera for Surveys (SLACS) survey (Bolton et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r2\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r2\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>) to produce a sample of 85 grade-A confirmed strong lenses and an additional 13 grade-B probable lenses (Auger et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r1\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r1\">2009</a>).</p><p>Strong lensing is the best probe of the distribution of mass in the transition region between the baryon-dominated central regions of galaxies and the dark matter halo (e.g., Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r22\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r22\">2005</a>). By combining strong-lensing aperture masses with lens-galaxy luminosities, sizes, and velocity dispersions, the SLACS collaboration has arrived at the following results (Treu et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r40\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r40\">2006</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r24\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r24\">2006</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r15\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r15\">2007</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r23\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r23\">2009</a>, see also Jiang &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r19\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r19\">2007</a>).\n</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The average total mass-density profile of early-type galaxies is nearly isothermal, corresponding to nearly flat galaxy rotation curves within the Einstein radius.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Models for early-type galaxies in which light linearly traces mass are falsified at <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 99.9% confidence even within the optical half-light radius.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The average weak-lensing signal out to a few hundred kiloparsecs around the SLACS lenses is consistent with an isothermal extrapolation of the strong-lensing constraints from the inner few kiloparsecs.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The average density structure of elliptical galaxies is universal and does not vary systematically with mass and exhibits a small but significant intrinsic scatter that is not significantly correlated with any other observable quantity.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">5.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The relationship between the lensing mass and the dynamical mass of SLACS lenses has a logarithmic slope of 1.03 \u00b1 0.04.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">6.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The variation in the dark matter fraction suggests a <em>bulge\u2013halo conspiracy</em>, with the combined rotation curve of both components together being flatter than that of either component independently.</div></li></ul><p>Many of these results were also found in earlier but smaller studies of lensed quasars (see e.g., Treu &amp; Koopmans <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r39\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r39\">2004</a>, or Rusin &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r33\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r33\">2005</a>, and references therein).</p><p>In order to conduct the next generation of large-scale structure surveys, the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III (SDSS-III) collaboration upgraded the Sloan Digital Sky Survey I (SDSS-I) optical spectrographs (York et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r48\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r48\">2000</a>) and initiated the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS; Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r12\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r12\">2011</a>). The significant hardware changes relative to SDSS-I are (1) an increase in the number of fibers from 640 to 1000, (2) smaller fiber diameters that subtend 2'' rather than 3'' on the sky, (3) volume-phase holographic gratings with increased efficiency, and (4) larger and more sensitive CCDs that increase throughput and wavelength coverage relative to SDSS-I. With this new configuration, BOSS is obtaining spectra of approximately 1.5 million luminous galaxies out to redshift <em>z</em> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.7 from mid-2009 to mid-2014. This sample complements the SDSS-I luminous red galaxy (LRG) data set that extends out to redshift <em>z</em> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.35. LRGs are luminous, elliptical, bulge-dominated galaxies, with remarkably uniform spectral energy distributions that are characterized by a strong break at 4000 \u00c5 (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r9\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r9\">2001</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r10\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r10\">2003</a>). The BOSS luminous galaxy sample is composed of a low-redshift (LOZ) sample designed to select LRGs with 0.2 <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <em>z</em> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.4 and a constant mass (CMASS) sample designed to select luminous galaxies with stellar masses in the range 10<sup>11</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <em>M</em><sub><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sstarf.gif\" alt=\"sstarf\" align=\"baseline\" /></sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> with 0.4 <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <em>z</em> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.7 (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r12\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r12\">2011</a>). Masters et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r29\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r29\">2011</a>) performed visual inspection of 240 BOSS targets in the COSMic Origins Survey field and determined that ~75% of BOSS galaxies are \"early-type,\" with the remainder \"late-type,\" and ~20% of BOSS galaxies are multiple systems. The combined sample will enable a baryonacoustic feature measurement (Eisenstein &amp; Hu <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r11\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r11\">1998</a>; Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r13\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r13\">2005</a>) of the distance\u2013redshift relation in several redshift bins.</p><p>As a consequence of this design and survey strategy, BOSS presents an opportunity to discover a sample of strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses at significant cosmological look-back time that is of comparable size and homogeneity to the SLACS sample at lower redshift. The two samples in combination may allow a unique study of the evolution of the structure of mass density and its dependence on other parameters such as stellar mass and stellar velocity dispersion.</p><p>A complementary sample of higher-redshift lenses discovered in the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Strong Lens Legacy Survey (SL2S; Cabanac et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r6\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r6\">2007</a>; Ruff et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r32\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r32\">2011</a>) suggests evolution in the slope of the mean-density profile to shallower slopes at higher redshifts. The key complementarity between SL2S and BOSS strong-lens surveys is that the former is more uniformly sensitive to selecting lenses across a range of angular scales (and hence mass scales), whereas the latter guarantees the spectroscopic redshift completeness for both lensing and lensed galaxies that is necessary for an accurate conversion from observed angular scales to physical mass scales.</p><p>This paper (Paper\u00a0I) is the first in a series presenting the initial catalog of 45 spectroscopically selected strong galaxy lens candidates discovered from the first partial year of BOSS data. We refer to this survey as the BOSS Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS). Of the initial 45 candidates, 44 were successfully observed with the Wide Field Camera (WFC) of the <em>HST</em> Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) under Program ID GO-12209 (PI: A. Bolton), resulting in 25 confirmed strong gravitational lenses, along with an additional 11 possible lenses with either very faint candidate lensed features or significant dust features complicating the analysis. The remaining target, SDSS\u00a0J0212+0027, is scheduled for <em>HST</em> visit. We show that the BELLS and SLACS lenses trace a single evolving massive galaxy population in terms of stellar mass, thus confirming the suitability of the combined sample to constrain the structural and dynamical evolution of massive galaxies down to the present-day universe.</p><p>This paper is organized as follows. The spectroscopic discovery method is described in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s2\">2</a>. The <em>HST</em> imaging data, reduction method, and the sample of 45 candidates are presented in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s3\">3</a>, and the photometric analysis including the B-spline fits used for lens-galaxy subtraction and the de Vaucouleurs (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r7\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r7\">1948</a>) models used for measuring the magnitudes and half-light radii are presented in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s4\">4</a>. We present our strong-lens modeling methods and results in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s5\">5</a>, employing singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) mass models in combination with both parametric and pixelized-grid source-plane surface-brightness models. A summary of results is presented in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s6\">6</a>. Throughout this paper, we assume a standard general-relativistic cosmology with parameters (<em>h</em>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub>, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>) = (0.7, 0.3, 0.7) (Larson et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r27\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r27\">2011</a>).</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s2\" name=\"apj413791s2\">2.\u00a0SPECTROSCOPIC CANDIDATE SELECTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The premise behind the spectroscopic strong-lens candidate selection of Bolton et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r4\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r4\">2004</a>) was to search for multiple background emission lines within the 3'' diameter solid angle covered by the SDSS-I spectroscopic fiber in the residual spectra found after subtracting best-fit galaxy templates to the foreground-galaxy spectrum (also see Warren et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r44\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r44\">1996</a>; Hewett et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r18\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r18\">2000</a>; Willis et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r46\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r46\">2005</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r47\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r47\">2006</a>). For our current search within the BOSS database, we apply much the same method, which is also described in Bolton et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r2\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r2\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>), to the 2'' diameter solid angle covered by the SDSS-III spectroscopic fiber. As a result of the blurring effect of atmospheric seeing, spectroscopic lens selection is efficient even at Einstein radii of \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 2'' (R. Arneson et\u00a0al. 2011, in preparation).</p><p>The full list of possible background emission lines for which we search is given in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t1\">1</a>, along with the corresponding maximum redshift to which they can be detected with either the SDSS-I or the more red-sensitive BOSS spectrographs. The spectra are based on SDSS-III imaging (Gunn et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r17\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r17\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r16\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r16\">1998</a>), available in the eighth SDSS public data release (DR8) (SDSS-III Collaboration: Aihara et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r35\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r35\">2011</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj413791t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0Emission-line Wavelengths</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791t1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 1\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb3727</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">3727.09</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\"
