I. A Large Spectroscopically Selected Sample of Lens Galaxies at Redshift ~0.5", "authors": ["Brownstein, Joel R.", "Bolton, Adam S.", "Schlegel, David J.", "Eisenstein, Daniel J.", "Kochanek, Christopher S.", "Connolly, Natalia", "Maraston, Claudia", "Pandey, Parul", "Seitz, Stella", "Wake, David A.", "Wood-Vasey, W. Michael", "Brinkmann, Jon", "Schneider, Donald P.", "Weaver, Benjamin A."], "author_address": ["AA(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA), AB(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA), AC(Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA), AD(Harvard College Observatory, 60 Garden Street, MS 20, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA), AE(Department of Astronomy and Center for Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, USA), AF(Department of Physics, Hamilton College, Clinton, NY 13323, USA), AG(Institute of Cosmology and Gravitation, University of Portsmouth, Portsmouth PO1 3FX, UK), AH(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA ; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, Piscataway, NJ 08854, USA), AI(University Observatory Munich, Scheinstrasse 1, 81679 M\u00fcnchen, Germany), AJ(Department of Astronomy, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520, USA), AK(Pittsburgh Center for Particle Physics, Astrophysics, and Cosmology (PITT-PACC), Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15260, USA), AL(Apache Point Observatory, P.O. Box 59, Sunspot, NM 88349, USA), AM(Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics and Institute for Gravitation and the Cosmos, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, USA), AN(Center for Cosmology and Particle Physics, New York University, New York, NY 10003, USA)"], "journal_name": "The Astrophysical Journal", "volume": "744", "publication_year": "2012/01/1", "start_page": "41", "keywords": ["galaxies: distances and redshifts", "galaxies: evolution", "galaxies: high-redshift", "gravitational lensing: strong", "large-scale structure of universe", "surveys", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Extragalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ApJ...744...41B", "abstract": "We present a catalog of 25 definite and 11 probable strong galaxy-galaxy gravitational lens systems with lens redshifts 0.4 &lt;~ z &lt;~ 0.7, discovered spectroscopically by the presence of higher-redshift emission lines within the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) of luminous galaxies, and confirmed with high-resolution Hubble Space Telescope (HST) images of 44 candidates. Our survey extends the methodology of the Sloan Lens Advanced Camera for Surveys survey (SLACS) to higher redshift. We describe the details of the BOSS spectroscopic candidate detections, our HST ACS image processing and analysis methods, and our strong gravitational lens modeling procedure. We report BOSS spectroscopic parameters and ACS photometric parameters for all candidates, and mass-distribution parameters for the best-fit singular isothermal ellipsoid models of definite lenses. Our sample to date was selected using only the first six months of BOSS survey-quality spectroscopic data. The full five-year BOSS database should produce a sample of several hundred strong galaxy-galaxy lenses and in combination with SLACS lenses at lower redshift, strongly constrain the redshift evolution of the structure of elliptical, bulge-dominated galaxies as a function of luminosity, stellar mass, and rest-frame color, thereby providing a powerful test for competing theories of galaxy formation and evolution. <P />Based on observations made with the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. These observations are associated with program 12209. Based on spectroscopic data from the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III.", "doi": "10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1112.3683", "issn": "0004-637X", "number": "1"}, "Paper text": "<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html lang=\"en\">\n\t<head>\n\t\t<meta http-equiv=\"X-UA-Compatible\" content=\"IE=edge,chrome=1\">\n\t\t\n\t\t\n<script <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">THE BOSS EMISSION-LINE LENS SURVEY (BELLS). I. A LARGE SPECTROSCOPICALLY SELECTED SAMPLE OF LENS GALAXIES AT REDSHIFT ~0.5<SUP>*</SUP>       </h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Joel R. Weaver</span><sup>13</sup></span></span>\n</p>\n\n<p class=\"small\" itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationIssue\">\n\t<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile Start-->\n<span class=\"wd-jnl-art-pub-date\">Published 2011 December 13</span> &bull; <!-- Start Copyright-->\n    <span itemprop=\"copyrightHolder\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-copyright\">\n       \t  \u00a9 2012. All rights reserved.</span><br />\n    <!-- end Copyright -->\n<span itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Periodical\" itemid=\"periodical\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-title article-toolbar-anchor\">\n\t<span itemprop=\"name\">\n\t\t<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">The Astrophysical Journal</a></span></span>,\n\t<span itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/PublicationVolume\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-vol nowrap\">\n\t<link itemprop=\"isPartOf\" itemid=\"periodical\" itemscope/>\n\t<span itemprop=\"volumeNumber\"><a href=\"/volume/0004-637X/744\" itemprop=\"url\">Volume 744</a></span></span>,\n<span itemprop=\"issueNumber\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-breadcrumb-issue\"><a href=\"/issue/0004-637X/744/1\" itemprop=\"url\"><!--Issue Number Tile Start-->\nNumber 1<!--Issue Number Tile End--></a></span>\n<!--Article Breadcrumb Tile End-->\n<!-- Start Focus issue title -->\n\t<!-- End focus issue title -->\n\t<span style=\"display: block\"><b>Citation</b> Joel R. href=\"https://plus.google.com/share?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F744%2F1%2F41\" title=\"Share a link to this content on your Google+ profile\" class=\"share-icon-link\">\n\t\t\t<img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/icon-google-plus.svg\" alt=\"Share on Google+\">\n\t</a>\n\t</li>\n\t<li id=\"wd-share-icon-mendeley\" class=\"share-icon-link\">\n\t<a href=\"https://www.mendeley.com/import/?doi=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F744%2F1%2F41\" title=\"Share on Mendeley\" class=\"share-icon-link\">\n\t\t\t<img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/icon-mendeley.svg\" alt=\"Share on Mendeley\">\n\t</a>\n\t</li>\n</ul>\n<div class=\"clear-fl\"></div>\n</div>\n\n</div>\n</div>\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1\">\n                <!-- Start Linked Articles note -->\n\t<!-- End Linked Articles note -->\n<!-- Article information starts. This includes author emails, affiliations, article published date, doi etc. -->\n\t<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 wd-jnl-art-article-info-wrapper\">\n      \t<div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n        \t<a id=\"wd-article-info-accordion\" href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide article information\">Article information</a>\n      \t</div>\n      \t<div class=\"reveal-content\">\n        \t<div class=\"article-meta\">\n          \t\t<!-- Start Affiliations --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-author-affiliations\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">Author affiliations</div><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>1</sup> Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>2</sup> New York, NY 10003, USA</p></div><!-- End Affiliations --><!-- Start Dates -->\n<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-dates\">\n        <div class=\"replica-h4\">Dates</div>\n        <p>\n            \n                Received <span itemprop=\"dateReceived\">2011 October 6</span><br />\n            \n                Accepted <span itemprop=\"dateAccepted\">2011 November 16</span><br />\n            \n                    Published <span itemprop=\"datePublished\">2011 December 13</span><br />\n                </p>\n    </div>\n<!-- End Dates -->\n\n<!-- Start Crossmark -->\n\t\t\t\t<!-- End Crossmark -->\n\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Peer Review Metrics -->\n<!-- End Peer Review Metrics -->\n\n<!--  Start Citation -->\n                    <!--  End Citation -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-doi\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<abbr title=\"digital object identifier\">DOI</abbr>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<p><a itemprop=\"sameAs\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\">https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41</a></p>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t<!-- End DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- End Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- Start Annotations -->\n <!-- End Annotations --><div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-aas-keywords\">\n\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">Keywords</div>\n\t\t<p><a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F10&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+distances+and+redshifts\">galaxies: distances and redshifts</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F13&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+evolution\">galaxies: evolution</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F18&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+high-redshift\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F46&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+strong\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F54&amp;code_desc=large-scale+structure+of+universe\">large-scale structure of universe</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=4%2F4&amp;code_desc=surveys\">surveys</a></p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!-- End Reprint Link --><!-- Start Journal RSS title=\"Create or edit your corridor alerts\">\n                <span class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create or edit your corridor alerts\n            </a>\n\n<!-- Start TOC Subjects Popup       <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n                        Receive alerts on all new research papers in American Astronomical Society\n                        (<span class=\"abbr__aas\">A&nbsp;A&nbsp;S&nbsp;</span>) journals as soon as they are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F744%2F1%2F41\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/744/1/41</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n                      <P>We present a catalog of 25 definite and 11 probable strong galaxy-galaxy gravitational lens systems with lens redshifts 0.4 <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <I>z</I> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.7, discovered spectroscopically by the presence of higher-redshift emission lines within the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS) of luminous galaxies, and confirmed with high-resolution <I>Hubble Space Telescope</I> (<I>HST</I>) images of 44 candidates. Our survey extends the methodology of the Sloan Lens Advanced Camera for Surveys survey (SLACS) to higher redshift. We describe the details of the BOSS spectroscopic candidate detections, our <I>HST</I> ACS image processing and analysis methods, and our strong gravitational lens modeling procedure. We report BOSS spectroscopic parameters and ACS photometric parameters for all candidates, and mass-distribution parameters for the best-fit singular isothermal ellipsoid models of definite lenses. Our sample to date was selected using only the first six months of BOSS survey-quality spectroscopic data. The full five-year BOSS database should produce a sample of several hundred strong galaxy-galaxy lenses and in combination with SLACS lenses at lower redshift, strongly constrain the redshift evolution of the structure of elliptical, bulge-dominated galaxies as a function of luminosity, stellar mass, and rest-frame color, thereby providing a powerful test for competing theories of galaxy formation and evolution.</P>       </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/744/1/41&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/744/1/41&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012ApJ...744...41B\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2012ApJ...744...41B&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2012ApJ...744...41B\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s1\" name=\"apj413791s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lensing produces unmistakably distorted, amplified, and multiplied images of a distant galaxy through the gravitational field of a foreground galaxy. This phenomenon provides a direct astrometric measurement of the total mass distribution within the interior of the lens galaxy, including luminous and dark components. Strong lensing on galactic scales was first suggested by Zwicky (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r49\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r49\">1937</a>) and first discovered by Walsh et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r42\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r42\">1979</a>). Since then, a number of dedicated and serendipitous surveys have produced a combined sample of over 200 galaxy-scale lens systems (for a recent review, see Treu <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r38\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r38\">2010</a>). Of the various survey methods, the most prolific means of identifying strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lens candidates is spectroscopic discovery, which provides evidence for two galaxies along one line of sight, along with precise measurements of the lens and source redshifts (Warren et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r44\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r44\">1996</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r4\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r4\">2004</a>). Images taken with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) or other high-resolution facilities then provide a confirmation of the lensing hypothesis and make precise (milliarcsecond) measurements of the relative positions of the components. This method has been employed by the Sloan Lens Advanced Camera for Surveys (SLACS) survey (Bolton et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r2\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r2\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>) to produce a sample of 85 grade-A confirmed strong lenses and an additional 13 grade-B probable lenses (Auger et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r1\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r1\">2009</a>).</p><p>Strong lensing is the best probe of the distribution of mass in the transition region between the baryon-dominated central regions of galaxies and the dark matter halo (e.g., Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r22\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r22\">2005</a>). By combining strong-lensing aperture masses with lens-galaxy luminosities, sizes, and velocity dispersions, the SLACS collaboration has arrived at the following results (Treu et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r40\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r40\">2006</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r24\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r24\">2006</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r15\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r15\">2007</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r23\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r23\">2009</a>, see also Jiang &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r19\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r19\">2007</a>).\n</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The average total mass-density profile of early-type galaxies is nearly isothermal, corresponding to nearly flat galaxy rotation curves within the Einstein radius.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Models for early-type galaxies in which light linearly traces mass are falsified at <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 99.9% confidence even within the optical half-light radius.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The average weak-lensing signal out to a few hundred kiloparsecs around the SLACS lenses is consistent with an isothermal extrapolation of the strong-lensing constraints from the inner few kiloparsecs.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The average density structure of elliptical galaxies is universal and does not vary systematically with mass and exhibits a small but significant intrinsic scatter that is not significantly correlated with any other observable quantity.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">5.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The relationship between the lensing mass and the dynamical mass of SLACS lenses has a logarithmic slope of 1.03 \u00b1 0.04.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">6.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The variation in the dark matter fraction suggests a <em>bulge\u2013halo conspiracy</em>, with the combined rotation curve of both components together being flatter than that of either component independently.</div></li></ul><p>Many of these results were also found in earlier but smaller studies of lensed quasars (see e.g., Treu &amp; Koopmans <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r39\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r39\">2004</a>, or Rusin &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r33\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r33\">2005</a>, and references therein).</p><p>In order to conduct the next generation of large-scale structure surveys, the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III (SDSS-III) collaboration upgraded the Sloan Digital Sky Survey I (SDSS-I) optical spectrographs (York et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r48\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r48\">2000</a>) and initiated the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS; Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r12\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r12\">2011</a>). The significant hardware changes relative to SDSS-I are (1) an increase in the number of fibers from 640 to 1000, (2) smaller fiber diameters that subtend 2'' rather than 3'' on the sky, (3) volume-phase holographic gratings with increased efficiency, and (4) larger and more sensitive CCDs that increase throughput and wavelength coverage relative to SDSS-I. With this new configuration, BOSS is obtaining spectra of approximately 1.5 million luminous galaxies out to redshift <em>z</em> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.7 from mid-2009 to mid-2014. This sample complements the SDSS-I luminous red galaxy (LRG) data set that extends out to redshift <em>z</em> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.35. LRGs are luminous, elliptical, bulge-dominated galaxies, with remarkably uniform spectral energy distributions that are characterized by a strong break at 4000 \u00c5 (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r9\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r9\">2001</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r10\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r10\">2003</a>). The BOSS luminous galaxy sample is composed of a low-redshift (LOZ) sample designed to select LRGs with 0.2 <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <em>z</em> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.4 and a constant mass (CMASS) sample designed to select luminous galaxies with stellar masses in the range 10<sup>11</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <em>M</em><sub><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sstarf.gif\" alt=\"sstarf\" align=\"baseline\" /></sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> with 0.4 <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> <em>z</em> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.7 (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r12\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r12\">2011</a>). Masters et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r29\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r29\">2011</a>) performed visual inspection of 240 BOSS targets in the COSMic Origins Survey field and determined that ~75% of BOSS galaxies are \"early-type,\" with the remainder \"late-type,\" and ~20% of BOSS galaxies are multiple systems. The combined sample will enable a baryonacoustic feature measurement (Eisenstein &amp; Hu <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r11\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r11\">1998</a>; Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r13\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r13\">2005</a>) of the distance\u2013redshift relation in several redshift bins.</p><p>As a consequence of this design and survey strategy, BOSS presents an opportunity to discover a sample of strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses at significant cosmological look-back time that is of comparable size and homogeneity to the SLACS sample at lower redshift. The two samples in combination may allow a unique study of the evolution of the structure of mass density and its dependence on other parameters such as stellar mass and stellar velocity dispersion.</p><p>A complementary sample of higher-redshift lenses discovered in the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Strong Lens Legacy Survey (SL2S; Cabanac et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r6\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r6\">2007</a>; Ruff et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r32\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r32\">2011</a>) suggests evolution in the slope of the mean-density profile to shallower slopes at higher redshifts. The key complementarity between SL2S and BOSS strong-lens surveys is that the former is more uniformly sensitive to selecting lenses across a range of angular scales (and hence mass scales), whereas the latter guarantees the spectroscopic redshift completeness for both lensing and lensed galaxies that is necessary for an accurate conversion from observed angular scales to physical mass scales.</p><p>This paper (Paper\u00a0I) is the first in a series presenting the initial catalog of 45 spectroscopically selected strong galaxy lens candidates discovered from the first partial year of BOSS data. We refer to this survey as the BOSS Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS). Of the initial 45 candidates, 44 were successfully observed with the Wide Field Camera (WFC) of the <em>HST</em> Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) under Program ID GO-12209 (PI: A. Bolton), resulting in 25 confirmed strong gravitational lenses, along with an additional 11 possible lenses with either very faint candidate lensed features or significant dust features complicating the analysis. The remaining target, SDSS\u00a0J0212+0027, is scheduled for <em>HST</em> visit. We show that the BELLS and SLACS lenses trace a single evolving massive galaxy population in terms of stellar mass, thus confirming the suitability of the combined sample to constrain the structural and dynamical evolution of massive galaxies down to the present-day universe.</p><p>This paper is organized as follows. The spectroscopic discovery method is described in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s2\">2</a>. The <em>HST</em> imaging data, reduction method, and the sample of 45 candidates are presented in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s3\">3</a>, and the photometric analysis including the B-spline fits used for lens-galaxy subtraction and the de Vaucouleurs (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r7\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r7\">1948</a>) models used for measuring the magnitudes and half-light radii are presented in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s4\">4</a>. We present our strong-lens modeling methods and results in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s5\">5</a>, employing singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) mass models in combination with both parametric and pixelized-grid source-plane surface-brightness models. A summary of results is presented in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s6\">6</a>. Throughout this paper, we assume a standard general-relativistic cosmology with parameters (<em>h</em>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub>, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>) = (0.7, 0.3, 0.7) (Larson et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r27\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r27\">2011</a>).</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s2\" name=\"apj413791s2\">2.\u00a0SPECTROSCOPIC CANDIDATE SELECTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The premise behind the spectroscopic strong-lens candidate selection of Bolton et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r4\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r4\">2004</a>) was to search for multiple background emission lines within the 3'' diameter solid angle covered by the SDSS-I spectroscopic fiber in the residual spectra found after subtracting best-fit galaxy templates to the foreground-galaxy spectrum (also see Warren et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r44\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r44\">1996</a>; Hewett et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r18\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r18\">2000</a>; Willis et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r46\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r46\">2005</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r47\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r47\">2006</a>). For our current search within the BOSS database, we apply much the same method, which is also described in Bolton et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r2\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r2\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>), to the 2'' diameter solid angle covered by the SDSS-III spectroscopic fiber. As a result of the blurring effect of atmospheric seeing, spectroscopic lens selection is efficient even at Einstein radii of \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 2'' (R. Arneson et\u00a0al. 2011, in preparation).</p><p>The full list of possible background emission lines for which we search is given in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t1\">1</a>, along with the corresponding maximum redshift to which they can be detected with either the SDSS-I or the more red-sensitive BOSS spectrographs. The spectra are based on SDSS-III imaging (Gunn et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r17\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r17\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r16\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r16\">1998</a>), available in the eighth SDSS public data release (DR8) (SDSS-III Collaboration: Aihara et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r35\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r35\">2011</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj413791t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0Emission-line Wavelengths</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791t1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 1\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Rest-frame</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">SDSS-I</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">SDSS-III</th>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Line</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Wavelength (\u00c5)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><em>z</em><sub>max</sub></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><em>z</em><sub>max</sub></th>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">(1)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(2)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(3)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(4)</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb3727</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">3727.09</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.44</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.63</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">\u00a0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">3729.88</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">\u00a0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">\u00a0</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">H\u03b4</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4102.89</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.22</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.39</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">H\u03b3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4341.68</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.10</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.26</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">H\u03b2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4862.68</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.87</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.02</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a04959</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4960.30</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.83</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.98</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a05007</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">5008.24</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.82</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.96</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">[N\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a06548</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">6549.86</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.39</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.50</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">H\u03b1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">6564.61</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.39</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.49</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">[N\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a06583</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">6585.27</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.38</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.49</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">[S\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a06716</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">6718.29</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.35</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.46</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">[S\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a06730</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">6732.68</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.35</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.46</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> Column 1 lists the emission lines used in the spectroscopic discovery of background emission-line sources and Column 2 shows the rest-frame vacuum wavelength of the emission line. Columns 3 and 4 provide the maximum redshift of the emission line detectable with the SDSS-I and SDSS-III spectrographs, respectively.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>We summarize our selection procedure here for completeness and to reflect minor changes in the implementation relevant for BOSS.\n</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Rescale the spectrum noise-vector estimates based upon the residual fluctuations in sky-subtracted sky-fiber spectra on the plate.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Select all objects both targeted and spectroscopically classified as galaxies, without any redshift warning flags. In the redshift analysis, only \"galaxy\" and \"star\" templates were allowed, since the inclusion of \"qso\" templates in the analysis of relatively low signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) BOSS galaxy spectra yields an unacceptable number of spurious classifications and redshifts. There were 133,852 galaxy spectra scanned in total.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Mask the positions of common emission lines in the spectra of the target galaxies, re-fit a model to the BOSS target-galaxy continuum using a basis of seven principal component analysis (PCA) eigenspectra generated as described in SDSS-III Collaboration: Aihara et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r35\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r35\">2011</a>) (versus four PCA eigenspectra used in the redshift analysis), and subtract this continuum model from the data.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Scan the residual spectra automatically for at least two of the lines H\u03b1, H\u03b2, [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a05007, [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a04959, or [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb3727 detected at 4\u03c3 significance or higher at a common redshift greater than that of the BOSS target. We refer to these as \"multi-line\" detections. There were 2898 multi-line hits.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">5.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Scan the residual spectra automatically for a single line detected at 6\u03c3 significance or higher that would be at a higher redshift than the BOSS target if identified as [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb3727. We refer to these as \"single-line\" detections. There were 8211 single-line hits.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">6.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Bin the single-line detections by observed-frame wavelength and prune those that are in highly overpopulated bins associated with night sky emission-line subtraction residuals.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">7.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Bin the single-line detections by target-galaxy rest-frame wavelength and prune those that are in highly overpopulated bins associated with imperfect foreground-galaxy feature masking and subtraction. There were 2137 single-line hits remaining after the cuts of Steps 6 and 7.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">8.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Veto any single-line [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb3727 identification that is more plausibly explained as H\u03b1, H\u03b2, or [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a05007, based upon the appearance of secondary lines at 3\u03c3 significance or higher. There were 1624 single-line hits remaining.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">9.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Remove any single-line detections also found in the multi-line search. There were 1268 single-line hits remaining.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">10.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Remove any detections in which the background redshift is not greater than the foreground redshift by the margin, <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> \u2212 <em>z</em><sub>S</sub> &#x2265; 0.05. There were 1303 multi-line hits and 741 single-line hits remaining.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">11.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Visually inspect the reduced spectra of all remaining selected systems at the position of the candidate background emission lines to remove obvious data-reduction/data-quality artifacts. There were 1226 multi-line hits and 507 single-line hits remaining after this step.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">12.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Inspect neighboring fiber spectra on each plate at the wavelength of the candidate background emission to rule out cross talk from bright emission lines in neighboring spectra and spatially localized auroral emission not subtracted by the global sky spectrum model.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">13.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Inspect the individual exposure spectra that were co-added to give the final detection spectrum to ensure that the candidate background emission-line feature is not present in only a single frame (as would be expected for, e.g., cosmic-ray hits).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">14.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Inspect the raw spectroscopic CCD data for all exposures at the position of [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb3727 emission for single-line candidates to ensure that the detection is not related to cosmetic blemishes in the CCD.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">15.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Compute a total S/N for all detections as the quadrature sum of the individual S/N values (i.e., \u03c3-values) of all lines in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t1\">1</a> detected at a significance of 3\u03c3 or higher\u2014including those which we do not employ as primary detection triggers in Step 4\u2014and rank candidates by this total S/N.</div></li></ul><p>In addition to ranking candidates by total S/N, we also select candidates to maximize lensing probability. Bolton et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>) show empirically that the lensing probability of a candidate system is a strongly increasing function of the predicted Einstein radius of the system using a simple singular isothermal sphere model based on the foreground-galaxy velocity dispersion and the redshifts of both foreground and background galaxies.</p><p>For BOSS lens candidates, we do not have precise velocity-dispersion measurements to use in this calculation nor do we want to introduce a selection bias by using luminosity as a proxy. Hence, we assume a fiducial velocity dispersion of 250\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> for all candidates and calculate a predicted \"Einstein radius\" given the foreground and background redshifts. This fiducial value is taken from the median of all well-measured velocity dispersions in the subset of the Bolton et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>) SLACS lens sample having early-type morphology. We then compute the physical radius subtended by this predicted Einstein radius at the redshift of the lens galaxy and require it to be greater than 4.5\u00a0kpc. Since no actual magnitude or velocity-dispersion information is used to make this cut, it can only bias the sample in terms of foreground- and background-redshift distributions. The cut corresponds to a predicted Einstein radius of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />84 at <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> = 0.4, and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />63 at <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> = 0.7. We verified that the sample selected by this cut does produce a reasonably uniform distribution of candidates over the available redshift range in the parent sample. The fiducial values of \u03c3<sub><em>v</em></sub> = 250\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub> = 4.5\u00a0kpc are not especially significant and can be traded off against one another with no effect on the selected sample. Effectively, our cut serves to favor candidates with higher background redshifts at a given foreground redshift and pushes to slightly smaller angular Einstein radii for higher-redshift lens galaxies.</p><p>These steps were carried out for all BOSS survey plates available prior to 2010 June 21: 239 unique plates, with an average of approximately 500 successful galaxy redshifts per plate. The systems are listed in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t2\">2</a>, including the BOSS pipeline redshift, the redshift of our candidate background emission-line source, and the BOSS photometry and velocity-dispersion measurements. The background emission-line spectra remaining after subtracting the best-fit foreground spectra are presented in Figure\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f1\">1</a>. The original detection of SDSS\u00a0J1221\u22120220 was an artifact of the spectroscopic data-reduction version used at the time of the <em>HST</em> target selection.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj413791f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f1a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f1a_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f1a\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f1a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f1a\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f1a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Spectroscopically discovered background emission lines in BELLS target galaxies. The black solid line shows the BOSS observed flux density, <em>f</em><sub>\u03bb</sub>, as a function of observed (lower axis) and rest-frame (upper axis) wavelengths. The blue dashed line shows the BOSS template fitted to the continuum of the foreground galaxy, and the red vertical line shows the wavelength of the background emission lines discovered in the differences between the observed flux and the best-fit template.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J230335.17+003703.2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4207-55475-0933</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.4582</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.9363</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">18.96 \u00b1 0.02</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.35 \u00b1 0.23</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">274 \u00b1 31</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><span class=\"small-caps\">cmass</span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> Column 1 provides the SDSS system name in terms of truncated J2000 R.A. and decl. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1DDMMSS.s. Column 2 provides the plate-MJD-fiber of the primary spectrum for the BOSS target (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r12\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r12\">2011</a>) as of v5_4_45 of the BOSS pipeline. Columns 3 and 4 provide the foreground BOSS spectroscopic redshift and the spectroscopically detected background emission-line source redshift, respectively. Columns 5 and 6 provide the BOSS de Vaucouleurs model <em>i</em>-band magnitudes and intermediate axis effective radii, respectively (Fukugita et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r14\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r14\">1996</a>; SDSS-III Collaboration: Aihara et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r35\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r35\">2011</a>). Column 7 provides the velocity dispersion computed by the BOSS pipeline (v5_4_45), uncorrected for aperture effects, using redshift-error marginalization and restricted stellar template sets as described in Shu et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r37\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r37\">2011</a>). Column 8 indicates whether the candidate was selected from the BOSS LOZ or CMASS sample. All the BELLS candidates in this table were observed (or will be observed in the case of SDSS\u00a0J0212+0027) by <em>HST</em> cycle 18 program ID GO-12209. The <em>HST</em>-ACS <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band properties are listed in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t3\">3</a>, including our classification of morphology, multiplicity, and lens grade, with our justification of BELLS confirmed gravitational lenses in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t4\">4</a>.\n<a name=\"apj413791t2fn1\" id=\"apj413791t2fn1\"></a><sup> a</sup>The lens redshift quoted for SDSS\u00a0J1159\u22120007 differs from the BOSS v5_4_45 galaxy redshift that will be reported in the ninth SDSS public data release (DR9) as <em>z</em>_<em>noqso</em>, due to the background emission-line flux.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t2_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t2_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s3\" name=\"apj413791s3\">3.\u00a0IMAGE PROCESSING</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The 45 systems identified in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t2\">2</a> were submitted for observation under <em>HST</em> cycle 18 program ID GO-12209, with one single-orbit visit per target using the <em>I</em>-band F814W filter, with four sub-exposures of approximately 500 s each in the ACS-WFC-DITHER-BOX pattern.</p><p>After each complete (and successful) visit, the individual flat-fielded (FLT) sub-exposure files generated by the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) <tt>CALACS</tt> pipeline were downloaded and reduced using <tt>ACSPROC</tt>\u2014a custom-built pipeline that was generalized from the SLACS version of the software described in Bolton et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>). For each visit, the steps in the current version of <tt>ACSPROC</tt>, implemented in the <tt>IDL</tt> programming language, are as follows.\n</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Extract a 1500 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 1500 pixel section of the FLT file for each sub-exposure, centered on the target, performing cosmic-ray rejection using <tt>L.A. COSMIC</tt> (van Dokkum <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r41\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r41\">2001</a>), and sky-level subtraction using the FLT <tt>MDRIZSKY</tt> <tt>FITS</tt> header, as determined by the STScI pipeline <tt>MULTIDRIZZLE</tt> reduction.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Obtain the approximate pixel-shift across sub-exposures through fast Fourier transform cross correlation and compute the centroid of the target galaxy for each sub-exposure by fitting an elliptical Moffat profile using the <tt>MPFIT2DPEAK</tt> nonlinear least-squares fitting function.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Rectify the sub-exposures onto a uniform 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />05 per pixel grid, with north up and east left, centered on the computed centroid. Rectify, with identical sampling, an appropriate model point-spread function (PSF) which was computed using the <tt>Tiny Tim</tt> <em>HST</em> PSF simulator (Krist <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r26\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r26\">1993</a>).</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Combine the sub-exposures into a single stacked image, with additional cosmic-ray rejection. Similarly, combine the PSF model.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">5.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Within a 280 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 280 (14'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 14'') section of the stacked image centered on the centroid of the target, separately mask potential lensed features, and probable non-lensed stars and galaxies.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">6.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Fit a set of elliptical radial B-spline models (Bolton et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r2\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r2\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r3\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r3\">2008</a>) to the masked stacked image using the <tt>MPFIT</tt> nonlinear least-squares implementation of the Levenberg\u2013Marquardt algorithm (Mor\u00e9 &amp; Wright <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r30\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r30\">1993</a>), allowing for either none or combinations of higher-order multipole moments, including the dipole, quadrupole, and octopole moments. Each of the B-spline models are manually inspected, and the masks are iteratively refined by the appearance of strong-lensing features in the B-spline-subtracted residuals. The B-spline fit which leads to the lowest \u03c7<sup>2</sup> without introducing obviously spurious small-scale structure is selected as the model for lens-galaxy subtraction.</div></li></ul><p>Step 4 leads to a combined and rectified image for all of the systems listed in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t2\">2</a>. Step 5 leads to a grade-A foreground-subtracted image for systems with clear and convincing evidence of multiple imaging for a subset of those systems. Systems with lensed features that are too low in surface brightness or contaminated by significant bright star light are classified as grade-B systems and systems that are unsuitable for lens modeling due to the absence of clearly identifiable counterimages are classified as grade-C systems. The systems without any identifiable lensed features are classified as grade-X systems for which we do not complete Step 5.</p><p>The results of the <tt>ACSPROC</tt> image processing, including the combined and rectified stacked images and the foreground-subtracted images are shown in Figure\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f2\">2</a> for all of the grade-A, -B, and -C systems. The combined and rectified stacked images for the grade-X systems are included in Figure\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f6\">6</a> in the <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791app1\">Appendix</a> for completeness.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj413791f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f2a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f2a_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f2c_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f2c\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f2c\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f2c\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f2c\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f2d_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0BELLS strong gravitational lens galaxies and foreground-subtracted images. The 36 grade-A, -B, and -C lenses discovered under <em>HST</em> cycle 18 program 12209. For each system, the left panel shows the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC F814W rectified and combined images with north up and east to the left, and the right panel reveals the lensed features which remain after the foreground galaxy has been subtracted by the B-spline method described in Section\u00a0<a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s3\">3</a>. Probable non-lensed extraneous features that were masked are circled. System properties from the BOSS data are listed in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t2\">2</a>, and those from the <em>HST</em>-ACS data are listed in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t3\">3</a>. Comments justifying our lens grade are provided in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t4\">4</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f2d\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f2d\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f2d\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f2d\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s4\" name=\"apj413791s4\">4.\u00a0PHOTOMETRIC ANALYSIS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>To compute standardized model magnitudes, effective radii, projected axis ratios, and position angles for the BELLS targets, we fit the images to two-dimensional ellipsoidal de Vaucouleurs luminosity profiles. These fits are performed over a 51'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 51'' square region centered on the target galaxies (approximately half the narrower dimension of the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC CCD aperture in which the targets were roughly centered). The 14'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 14'' masks created with our <tt>ACSPROC</tt> software described in Step\u00a05 of Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s3\">3</a> are applied in the central regions; stars and neighboring galaxies outside the manually masked area are masked with a single-step \"clipping\" of pixels that deviate by more than four standard deviations from the model. The fits are performed using the <tt>MPFIT2DFUN</tt> procedure in the <tt>IDL</tt> programming language, using a flat-weighted inverse variance, and include convolution with the appropriate rectified and stacked <tt>Tiny Tim</tt> PSF (Krist <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r26\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r26\">1993</a>). The initial optimization is done by sampling the model at one point per data pixel and repeated with a 5 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 5 sub-sampling per pixel.</p><p>The <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band apparent magnitudes are computed from the full (not truncated) analytic integral of the best-fit de Vaucouleurs model and provided in Table\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t3\">3</a>. We also report the corrections for Galactic extinction from Schlegel et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r34\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r34\">1998</a>). Photometric stellar masses are computed from the extinction corrected <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band apparent magnitudes using the Maraston et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r28\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r28\">2009</a>) LRG photometric stellar population model with a Salpeter initial mass function. We use the intermediate axis effective radius (the geometric mean of the major and minor axes).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj413791t3\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 3.</b>\u00a0<em>HST</em>-ACS <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band Properties of BELLS Systems</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\"
