rowspan=\"1\">0.806</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">105.6</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">22.32</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">3.28</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1545+2748</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.210</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.418</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">99.0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">22.58</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4.35</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1601+2138</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.858</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.906</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">164.6</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">22.84</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">3.50</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1611+1705</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.580</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.740</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4.3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">22.13</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2.27</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1631+1854</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.634</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.878</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">35.3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">20.41</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">19.15</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1637+1439</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.650</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.750</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">122.5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">22.99</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">10.65</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J2122+0409</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.580</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.634</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">119.7</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">22.31</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">5.73</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J2125+0411</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.204</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.821</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">83.0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">21.11</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">4.32</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J2303+0037</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.016</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.391</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">88.8</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">23.10</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">8.06</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> The method used to compute the best-fit SIE model parameters is described in Section\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj413791s5\">5</a>. Column 1 provides the SDSS system name in terms of truncated J2000 R.A. and decl. in the format HHMM\u00b1DDMM. Column 2 provides the best-fit SIE model Einstein radius. Column 3 provides the best-fit minor to major axis ratio for the SIE models. Column 4 provides the major axis position angle for the SIE models, measured east from north. Column 5 provides the number of S\u00e9rsic models added to the source plane to provide the best fit. Column 6 provides the <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band magnitude of the lensed source. Column 7 provides the magnification of the lensed source.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t5_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t5_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791s6\" name=\"apj413791s6\">6.\u00a0SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We present 44 of the 45 targets observed-to-date in the BELLS from the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC cycle 18 program ID GO-12209 imaging program. The BELLS catalog presently includes 25 grade-A strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses complete with lens and source redshifts, <em>I</em><sub>814</sub>-band foreground-galaxy photometry, and SIE models. This represents a significant expansion of the SLACS survey, extending the lens redshifts to <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0.66, and with source redshifts extended to <em>z</em><sub>S</sub> <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/sime.gif\" alt=\"sime\" align=\"baseline\" /> 1.52. The combined SLACS and BELLS catalog provides a homogeneous sample of strong-lens galaxies at significant cosmological look-back times. Future papers in this series will apply the combined SLACS and BELLS samples to the analysis of the structure and evolution of massive elliptical galaxies.</p><p>We have described the use of our <tt>ACSPROC</tt> <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC image processing software to make luminosity measurements and to produce our <tt>BIZZLE</tt> data product. We then analyze the <tt>BIZZLE</tt> data using our <tt>ACSLENS</tt> lens-modeling software to make parameterized and pixelized lens models. Our analysis demonstrates that simple SIE lens models, combined with multiple S\u00e9rsic ellipsoid models of the lensed background galaxies, can reproduce the lensed image configurations in great detail, and our pixelized source models reproduce more detailed features in the lensed images and add finer structure to the de-lensed source model.</p><p>The high success rate of our <em>HST</em> imaging program demonstrates that the spectroscopic strong-lens selection methodology can be successfully applied to the BOSS spectroscopic database even though BOSS is targeting a more distant\u2014and hence fainter\u2014galaxy population than SDSS-I. The probability of finding a galaxy\u2013galaxy lens using the spectroscopic discovery method was considered in Dobler et\u00a0al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r8\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r8\">2008</a>) for the SLACS survey, including selection effects such as the finite size of the spectroscopic fiber (which selects against large separation lenses), and the effectiveness of spectral noise modeling (which selects against sources that have redshifted emission lines coincident with strong emission lines in the sky). The probability that a galaxy\u2013galaxy lens would be spectroscopically discovered from either the SDSS-I or SDSS-III spectra, and lead to a confirmed lens, is under consideration in R. Arneson et\u00a0al. (2011, in preparation) using a Monte Carlo simulation to measure the effects of variation in the lens mass, ellipticity, and morphology, source extent, and the logarithm slope of the lens luminosity profile.</p><p>The strong-lensing measurements presented in this work afford a unique opportunity to test the results of theoretical models and numerical simulations of galaxy formation, merging, and evolution. This is due to the fact that strong-lensing measures the projected mass inside the aperture defined by the Einstein radius, in a nearly model-independent sense, and without need for modeling of stellar populations and luminosity evolution.</p><p>In comparison with the SDSS-I spectra of the SLACS lens sample, the BOSS spectra for the BELLS sample have significantly lower signal to noise. Hence, the resulting velocity-dispersion measurements for the BELLS sample are correspondingly noisier and more care must be taken in interpreting these measurements in the context of dynamical galaxy modeling. Work in preparation will present a joint analysis of all BELLS lenses that marginalizes over the full velocity-dispersion likelihood function for individual spectra (see Shu et\u00a0al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r37\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r37\">2011</a>). Deeper spectroscopy with large ground-based telescopes can provide more precise stellar velocity-dispersion measurements.</p><p>We note that the BOSS spectroscopic database as of summer 2011, which will constitute the ninth SDSS public data release (DR9), contains 819 unique BOSS plates with an average of approximately 600 successfully redshifted galaxies per plate. (The increase in the number of spectroscopically confirmed galaxies per plate was produced by a combination of improvements in targeting, hardware, operations, and analysis software during the BOSS commissioning phase and early operations.) Thus, DR9 is at least a fourfold increase over the sample we used here. The final BOSS sample, to be completed in mid-2014 and released at the end of that year, will be an order of magnitude increase over the sample used here. In addition, ongoing BOSS spectroscopic pipeline development (including implementation of the two-dimensional PSF-based extraction algorithm of Bolton &amp; Schlegel <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj413791r5\" id=\"fnref-apj413791r5\">2010</a>) continues to increase the quality of the reduced spectra and redshift/classification analysis for BOSS significantly. Hence, there will be at least several hundred strong lenses to be found in BOSS spectroscopy at the end of the survey, offering the possibility of measuring the cosmic evolution of the relationship between mass-density structure and stellar mass, luminosity, and rest-frame color, in great quantitative detail.</p></div>\n<div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Support for program 12209 was provided by NASA through a grant from the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. This work has made extensive use of the Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey, part of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III (SDSS-III). Funding for SDSS-III has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation, and the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science. The SDSS-III Web site is <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"url_link\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.sdss3.org/\">http://www.sdss3.org/</a>. SDSS-III is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS-III Collaboration including the University of Arizona, the Brazilian Participation Group, Brookhaven National Laboratory, University of Cambridge, University of Florida, the French Participation Group, the German Participation Group, the Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, the Michigan State/Notre Dame/JINA Participation Group, Johns Hopkins University, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Max Planck Institute for Astrophysics, New Mexico State University, New York University, Ohio State University, Pennsylvania State University, University of Portsmouth, Princeton University, the Spanish Participation Group, University of Tokyo, University of Utah, Vanderbilt University, University of Virginia, University of Washington, and Yale University. J.R.B. and A.S.B. acknowledge the hospitality of the Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Astronomie, where a portion of this work was completed. C.S.K. is supported by NSF grant AST-1004756.</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj413791app1\" name=\"apj413791app1\">APPENDIX</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The combined and rectified stacked images for the grade-X systems are included in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj413791f6\">6</a> for completeness. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t6\">6</a> gives the comments justifying the lens grade of \"X\".</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj413791f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/744/1/41/Full/apj413791f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0BELLS grade-X non-lens galaxies. The eight non-lenses, discovered to-date under <em>HST</em> cycle 18 program ID GO-12209, Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t2\">2</a> presents their properties as derived from the BOSS data, and Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t3\">3</a> presents those derived from the <em>HST</em> data. For each system, the panel shows the <em>HST</em> ACS-WFC F814W rectified and combined images with north up and east to the left. Comments justifying the lens grade of \"X\" are provided in Table\u00a0<a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj413791t6\">6</a>. The color scale is provided in Figure\u00a0<a href=\"#apj413791f2\">2</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj413791f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadFigure/figure/apj413791f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj413791f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj413791f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj413791t6\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 6.</b>\u00a0BELLS Grade-X Non-lens Galaxies</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj413791t6\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t6_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 6\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">System Name</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Justification</th>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">(1)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(2)</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody><tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J0757+4313</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Two components with spiral structure; any lensing features are difficult to disentangle.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J0837+4937</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Late-type with faint candidate features, but with no evidence of multiple imaging.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1117\u22120133</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Pronounced asymmetry in the foreground galaxy plus possible spiral and dust features. Possible lensed background sources cannot be unambiguously modeled given single-band imaging.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1221\u22120220</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Double nucleus in the foreground galaxy, with no evidence of background-galaxy features.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1345\u22120129</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Faint possible background-galaxy features to the west, but without plausible evidence of strong lensing.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1615+2056</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Possible candidate arc extending to the northwest and to the east, but the system is difficult to interpret as a lens.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1618+1930</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">No obvious background features, but spiral structure and/or dust in the foreground galaxy complicates interpretation.</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">SDSS\u00a0J1627+1910</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Possible faint background-galaxy features to the northeast, but without evidence of strong lensing.</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong> Column 1 provides the SDSS system name in terms of truncated J2000 R.A. and decl. in the format HHMM\u00b1DDMM. Column 2 provides our justification for the lens grade of \"X\" (non-lenses).\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t6_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/744/1/41\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/744/1/41/suppdata/apj413791t6_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apj413791fn1\" id=\"apj413791fn1\">*\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>Based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>, obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. I have amended it to turn of JS on all IE browsers less than 10.\n\tThis is due to a function in the iop.jquery.toolbar.js line 35/36. Licensed MIT */\n\tfunction loadJS( src, cb ){\n\t  \"use strict\";\n\t  var ref = window.document.getElementsByTagName( \"script\" )[ 0 ];\n\t  var script = window.document.createElement( \"script\" );\n\t  script.src = src;\n\t  script.async = true;\n\t  ref.parentNode.insertBefore( script, ref );\n\t  if (cb && typeof(cb) === \"function\") {\n\t\tscript.onload = cb;\n\t  }\n\t  return script;\n\t}\n\n\tloadJS( \"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/js/scripts.min.js\" );\n\n  }\n</script>\n\n<script type=\"text/javascript\">window.NREUM||(NREUM={});NREUM.info={\"errorBeacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"licenseKey\":\"b2bfaae1b6\",\"agent\":\"\",\"beacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"applicationTime\":371,\"applicationID\":\"723879338\",\"transactionName\":\"NAAHMUBVCENSABFZXg1KLzZiGzF1cU4sfndMDxYVQRsFX14OCl4eDwQcCkdASFpAEw==\",\"queueTime\":0}</script></body>\n</html>", "Status": "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": ">Based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>, obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555.
